description: From Middle English frouncen, from Old French froncir "to wrinkle, frown", from Frankish *hrunkiju (“a wrinkle”), from Proto-Germanic *hrunkijō, *hrunkitō (“fold, wrinkle”), from Proto-Indo-European *(s)ker- (“to turn, bend”). Akin to Old High German runza "fold, wrinkle, crease" (German Runzel "wrinkle"), Middle Dutch ronse "frown", Old Norse hrukka "wrinkle, crease" (Icelandic hrukka "wrinkle, crease, ruck"). More at ruck2.

entries.meaning: A canker in the mouth of a hawk.

verbs.description: frounce (third-person singular simple present frounces, present participle frouncing, simple past and past participle frounced)

examples: He frounced his brow, and from his scornful eye
Shot wrath indignant, and disdain and pride,

entries.meaning: To gather into or adorn with plaits, as a dress.
